Graphical abstract The speciation of Ni in spent Fluid Catalytic Cracking catalysts is studied. Carefully performed XRD analyses with NiO/SiO2 samples used as calibration standards, demonstrate that the presence of NiO as a separate phase is reliably detected also for NiO concentration close to 0.1 wt% (1000ppmw). Actually, both on real spent FCC catalysts (ECAT's) and on artificially contaminated industrial FCC catalysts, NiO is not detectable as a separate phase, even after contamination of the order of 15,000ppmw of Ni. SEM–EDS experiments provide evidence of a largely preferential location of Ni on alumina particles present in the FCC catalyst mixture, thus acting as “nickel traps”. XRD, UV–vis and TPR data confirm that Ni deposits on alumina particles forming a hardly reducible surface and subsurface layer, giving rise to a solid whose composition is Ni x Al2O3+x with x <<0.25. As a result of this, the formation of extended Ni metal particles in the raiser reactor is avoided, being their unwanted dehydrogenation activity essentially eliminated. The absence of bulk NiO in the spent FCC catalysts (at least when Ni content is in the range 2000–10,000ppmw) allows the classification of this material as a non-hazardous waste. Keywords Nickel speciation Catalyst for FCC Fluid Catalytic Cracking catalyst Spent catalyst Refinery waste Nickel speciation Non-dangerous waste 1 Introduction Catalysis is critical in the industry as demonstrated by the fact that ∼90% of the chemical, petrochemical and oil refining processes involve at least a catalytic step [1]. The development of new transformation processes is linked to the availability of increasingly more efficient catalysts able of producing a given chemical with high productivity, selectivity (thereby limiting the formation of useless byproducts) and low energy consumption. The current trend is to prefer the heterogeneous solid catalysts with respect to the homogeneous ones, i.e. those operating in the same phase of the reagent mixture (for example, mineral or Lewis acids operating in the liquid phase for acid-catalyzed reactions). The advantages deriving from the use of solid catalysts are multiple: they typically have a high selectivity, do not present problems of corrosion, can be easily separated from the products, have a long life and can be regenerated several times without significantly losing their catalytic properties. The overall life of a solid catalyst depends on its characteristics and the process that is being used. During its life cycle, a solid catalyst deactivates gradually for several causes. A typical phenomenon concerns the deposition of heavy organic products, which make progressively inaccessible the active sites; in these cases the functionality is restored by calcining the deactivated catalyst under appropriate conditions. In other cases, the deactivation occurs by poisoning of the active sites by elements contained in trace amounts in the feedstock (e.g., metals, sulfur) or by the modification of the local structure of the sites themselves induced by particular reaction and/or regeneration conditions. In any case, when the performances of the catalyst drop below the limits of acceptability, it is fully replaced with a batch of fresh catalyst. The fate of the spent catalyst, in turn, depends on its characteristics and composition. If technically feasible and economically favorable, the spent catalyst is sent to the recovery of its most valuable components or conferred to industries (e.g. cement, steel factories). In less favorable cases, the spent catalyst is treated as waste and disposed of according to existing regulations, with obvious economic and environmental implications substantially related to the classification of the waste itself. The problem is certainly not negligible, especially when it is considered the enormous amounts of spent catalyst that are yearly produced in the world by certain processes. One of these is certainly the Fluid Catalytic Cracking (FCC), a key refining process employed to convert heavy oil fractions (e.g. vacuum gas-oil, VGO) into lighter products, mainly high octane gasoline and an olefin-rich gas, using a zeolite-based catalyst appropriately designed to be used in a recirculating fluidized bed reactor [2–4]. The conditions used in the FCC process are very stressful for the catalyst: during the numerous reaction-regeneration cycles, it undergoes structural modifications that, in the long run, are responsible for the loss of activity. Furthermore, a progressive accumulation of metals (in particular Ni, V and Fe contained from a few to over 250ppmw in the crude oils [5]) takes place and this must be properly monitored to avoid the rapid degradation of the catalyst as well as the promotion of undesired reactions. Among these metals, Ni is certainly one of the most critical because, under the operating conditions, it can promote dehydrogenation reactions, which enhance the tendency of coke formation at the expenses of gasoline yield and increase the production of gas as well as of hydrogen. Moreover, the so-called “equilibrated catalysts” (ECAT's) contain, in the most common cases, 2000–5000ppmw of Ni, and that generates also serious concerns for the disposal of the spent catalyst. In fact, a number of nickel compounds are classified as carcinogenic or toxic to reproduction, class 1A or 1B [6]. In the case of FCC catalysts, the speciation of Ni has still not been unambiguously defined. Thus, it must be supposed it to be present as NiO (nickel oxide, mineral name bunsenite), and for this the limit of 0.1 wt% applies for the classification of the spent catalyst as hazardous wastes (Classification, Labelling and Packaging Regulation 790/2009/CE). In the absence of precise information on the speciation of Ni in spent FCC catalysts, it is difficult to assign the correct hazardous properties to the spent FCC catalyst when is disposed or recovered as a waste. Usually in such conditions, a precautionary approach, based on the assumption that the Ni is present on the catalyst in the most hazardous form (as Ni oxide or sulfides, depending on the catalyst and on the process), is adopted. Such approach induces to overestimate the real level of hazard in the waste treatment and to inappropriate disposal procedures. Just to give an idea, it was reported that a FCC plant operating in a medium-size refinery (230kbbld−1) with a catalyst inventory of 200t, consumes 1000t of catalyst per year [7]. The relevance of this issue is given by the significant worldwide consumption of FCC catalyst, which in 2011 amounted to the impressive value of 627kt [8]. To limit these effects, manufacturers have developed catalysts consisting of matrices able to bind the feed metals, reducing their undesired effects. In the case of Ni its actual state in the FCC catalyst was only occasionally discussed in the literature, especially in relation to its role in the deactivation [9–11]. The interpretations of the results obtained using different characterization techniques, however, disagree largely and no definite answers were provided about its actual state in spent FCC catalysts. In an effort to give a definitive answer to this problem, we have focused attention on the detectability of the phase responsible for the classification as hazardous of the spent FCC catalyst (NiO and bunsenite), developed on model systems an analytical procedure able to verify the limit of detection of the phase of interest and verified on a series of real spent catalyst from different refineries. 2 The FCC process and catalyst FCC is a key technology in oil refinery because it is used to convert vacuum distillates and residues into more valuable products, mainly gasoline but even middle distillates and light olefins (e.g., propylene, butenes). The cracking reaction is endothermic and increases the number of moles of products respect to the feed. It is therefore favored at high temperature and low pressure. The catalyst undergoes coking very rapidly and should be frequently regenerated. The FCC configuration schematized in Fig. 1 takes into account these concepts: the preheated feed (vacuum gas-oil, VGO) is fed at the bottom of the riser (the reactor) where it is mixed with the catalyst. The cracking reactions occur in the riser where the volume expansion helps the mix catalyst/feed to move upwards very rapidly (2–10s). Then, the mix is sent to the stripper where the hydrocarbons are separated from the coked catalyst, which is finally steam-stripped from the adsorbed volatile products. The coked catalyst is finally sent to the regeneration unit, where the coke is burned off with air for 10–15min; the regenerated catalyst, at a temperature of 700+°C due to the exothermal combustion of coke, returns to the bottom of the riser ready for a new cycle. Fig. 1 also shows the products typically generated by FCC and their finally destination use. Whereas the relative yields depend on the characteristics of the feed (e.g. paraffinic or aromatic) and of the catalytic system, olefins, cracking naphtha and LCO are the most valuable streams. Such a complex pool of products originates from several secondary reactions (e.g. isomerization, cyclization, dehydrogenation, H-transfer), which occur together with the cracking [3,8]. In order to maximize the yields of desired streams, it is necessary to optimize the catalytic system. The actual FCC catalyst consists of spherical particles of 70–80μm average diameter (20–120μm range), suitable for the application in the fluidized circulating reactor. A deeper insight into the particles evidences the complexity of the catalyst, which is composed by zeolite Y crystals dispersed in an active matrix of alumina or silica-alumina, together with clay particles (Fig. 2 ). A fundamental characteristic of the FCC catalyst is represented by the porosity. The size of the pores of zeolite Y (12-ring opening with free dimensions of ∼7.5Å, interconnecting large spherical supercages with free diameter of ∼12.5Å) limits the accessibility of the molecules to the active sites. It is therefore necessary to tune the porosity of the matrix during the preparation procedure to generate a hierarchical porosity spanning from macro- to meso- to micropores. The improvements of the FCC catalyst achieved during the last 40 years have regarded not only the zeolite phase but even the other components, because (differently from what observed in other shaped catalyst used, e.g., in petrochemical processes) the matrix is not merely a binder but it constitutes itself an active component, displaying catalytic activity towards heavy molecules. The formation of macro- and mesoporosity is, therefore, necessary both for assuring the diffusion of the fluid within the catalyst particle and for providing the space necessary for cracking large molecules. Concerning the deposition of metals, it must be remarked that they will tend to stay in an oxidized state after regeneration in air, but can reduce in the raiser. Vanadium, in addition to the promotion of undesired reactions, may have dramatic effects on the stability of the zeolite component due to the volatility of H3VO4 formed in the regenerator. Nickel tends to reduce to metallic state in the raiser and worsens the catalyst properties: metallic Ni is an effective dehydrogenation catalyst, promoting the formation of H2 and coke when present on the FCC catalysts. The early solution of this problem comprises the addition of small amounts of Sb compounds to the feed in order to favor the formation of Ni–Sb alloys substantially inactive in the dehydrogenation reaction [12]. A modern approach is to introduce additional components to the catalyst mixture to trap and deactivate V and Ni in the catalyst, as it will be discussed below. 3 Experimental 3.1 Materials 3.1.1 ECAT catalysts ECAT catalysts (equilibrated catalysts) are spent catalysts coming from FCC plants operating in different Italian refineries. We preferred to examine a large case series of samples with different origin, that means used in different conditions, with different feedstocks (usually vacuum gas-oil, VGO) and with variable content of metals (in particular Ni). For reasons of confidentiality, it is not possible to report the specific conditions of use as well as the nature and characteristics of the feedstocks employed. However, this information is not decisive for the purpose of the present work, which is aimed solely to determine the phases that nickel forms in the reaction-regeneration conditions of the FCC process. We emphasize the importance of having real samples impossible to reproduce in the laboratory. 3.1.2 Preparation of reference NiO/SiO2 samples A series of samples of silica gel with increasing content of NiO (samples SIL-X) has been prepared with the following procedure: a known amount of high purity grade silica gel Davisil 923 (100–200 mesh, Sigma-Aldrich), previously calcined at 540°C for 3h under nitrogen flow, is charged in a round-bottom flask and cyclohexene is added to incipient wetness. Successively, the required amount of nickel 2-ethylhexanoate (Sigma-Aldrich) is added and after homogenization the solvent is removed by mild heating under vacuum. The dried sample is finally calcined at 700°C for 3h under air flow to remove the organic components and produce NiO. Four samples with nominal Ni contents of 1000, 5000, 15,000 and 75,000ppmw have been prepared. 3.1.3 Preparation of reference Ni2+/Al2O3 samples The pure alumina support material used to prepare these materials (denoted as AL-X) is Puralox SBA 200 from Sasol (190m2/g). Ni-alumina samples have been prepared by a conventional wet impregnation using Ni(NO3)2·6H2O water solution, followed by calcination at 600°C for 5h. Three samples will be considered here, AL-1, AL-2 and Al-3, nominally containing 4.7, 13.3 and 26.0 wt% of Ni, corresponding to 47,000, 133,000 and 260,000ppmw, respectively. 3.1.4 Treatment of fresh FCC catalyst with Ni2+ The same procedure used for the preparation of NiO on silica was applied for treating a fresh FCC catalyst with increasing amounts of nickel 2-ethylhexanoate (samples CTZ-X). Four samples with nominal Ni content of 1000, 5000, 15,000 and 75,000ppmw have been prepared and, after calcination, all the samples were hydrothermally deactivated at 760°C for 12h with vapor only. 3.2 Characterization Elemental composition of the samples was determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP OES) using a Yobin-Ivon Mod. Ultima II instrument. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed with a PANalytical X’PERT vertical diffractometer equipped with a scintillator detector and a curved graphite crystal secondary monochromator. Data were collected in the 4°≤2θ ≤70° angular region, with 0.03° 2θ step length and 24s/step accumulation time; the CuKα radiation (λ =1.54178Å) was used. SEM characterizations were performed with two different field emission scanning electron microscopes: a ZEISS SUPRA 40 VP and a JEOL JSM 7600F. The former is equipped with an Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) system with a Si(Li) detector interfaced with a “INCA Energy 450×3″ system by Oxford and was used for EDS quantitative analyses. The latter is even equipped with a EDS system by Oxford, that is a silicon drift detector (SDD) interfaced with an INCA Energy 350 and was used for EDS mapping. ECAT samples for quantitative EDS analysis were grinded, suspended in ethanol and exposed to ultrasonic vibrations to decrease the aggregation. A drop of the resultant mixture was finally deposed on a Lacey Carbon copper grid. EDS mapping, instead, was collected on un-grinded ECAT FCC particles, embedded into epoxy resin, polished and carbon coated. Diffuse Reflectance UV–vis–NIR spectra have been recorded with a Jasco V570 instrument. Temperature programmed reduction tests (H2-TPR) were performed with a Micromeritics Pulse ChemiSorb 2705 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), on as-calcined Ni2+/Al2O3 samples using a 10% H2/Ar gas mixture, while the temperature is ramping up from RT to 900°C at a rate of 15°C/min. 4 Results 4.1 The amount of nickel in ECAT catalysts The nickel content in spent equilibrated FCC catalysts (ECAT's) is quite variable according to different sources, likely depending on the Ni content in the feedstock and on time on stream. Ni content can vary from 100 to 350ppmw to higher values, even 12,000ppmw [9,13,14]. According to data published very recently by a main catalyst producer [15] the nickel content in ECAT's is systematically growing. The average level is now 3600ppmw for the catalysts used in Asia and 1363ppmw in America. The elemental analyses in the ECAT catalysts under investigation are reported in Table 1 . The Ni content is in the range 1650–5160ppmw, in agreement with most of the above cited literature. 4.2 XRD as a tool for determining the presence of NiO Aim of the investigation was to determine the status of Ni in the FCC equilibrium catalysts (ECAT), with particular attention to NiO in concentrations ≥0.1 wt%. Therefore, the analytical problem is not to determine just the total Ni content in the FCC catalyst, but to proceed to its speciation, namely to identify and quantify the phase(s) in which the metal is distributed. When Ni is present in high amounts (at the level of a few percent by weight), this aspect can be effectively examined by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD). Taking into account the conditions of FCC experiments and of our model sample preparation procedures, we can exclude the formation of amorphous NiO, only crystalline NiO, detectable by XRD, being possibly present. However, in the case of ECAT catalysts the total content of Ni is in the range 1500–5200ppmw (equivalent to ca. 1900–6600ppmw of NiO) and this raises doubts about the actual possibility of using the XRD technique for assessing the presence of phases involving this metal. To evaluate, at least qualitatively, the presence of NiO (or other Ni-containing Ni phases) is therefore necessary to collect XRD data in an extremely accurate way, with accumulation times sufficiently long to increase the signal/noise ratio and highlight even weak scattering phenomena associated with these crystalline phases. To determine the lower detection limit for NiO and to check the state of Ni in FCC catalysts, the XRD analyses of the following samples were carried out: a) Four samples of amorphous silica impregnated with increasing amounts of Ni (in form of 2-ethylhexanoate) and subsequently calcined in air at 700°C in air to transform Ni in bunsenite (NiO) (samples SIL-X). b) Three samples of alumina impregnated with high amounts of Ni starting from Ni(NO3)2·6H2O water solution, followed by calcination at 600°C for 5h (samples AL-X). c) Four samples of a fresh FCC catalyst impregnated with increasing amounts of nickel 2-ethylhexanoate, successively calcined in air at 700°C and hydrothermally deactivated at 760°C for 12h with vapor only (samples CTZ-X). d) Ten ECAT samples downloaded from the FCC plants operating in different Italian refineries (samples ECAT-X). The compositional data related to the samples under investigation are listed in Table 1. 4.2.1 Samples NiO/silica gel The analysis of the samples SIL-1–SIL-4 is required to define the detection limit of NiO (bunsenite) and to construct a calibration curve useful for assessing the amount of bunsenite eventually present in the catalysts. The XRD patterns of these samples are shown in Fig. 3 . As expected, bunsenite is the only crystalline phase present, while silica does not show any sort of ordering, even partial, of the structure. In general, it would seem that only in the XRD patterns of samples with Ni loadings higher that 4408ppmw (sample SIL-2) it is possible to observe the presence of NiO; however, a more detailed examination of the XRD patterns allows assessing that this phase is present also in sample SIL-1, containing 901ppmw of Ni. This is confirmed by Fig. 3b, where it is reported a magnification of the XRD patterns in the angular region 42≤2θ ≤45°: the most intense reflection of bunsenite (200) is clearly visible and its intensity easily measurable. This demonstrates that adopting very accurate measurement conditions, especially for what concerns the accumulation times deliberately kept high (24s/step), it is possible to detect very small concentrations of NiO (1147ppmw, 0.115 wt%). This is extremely important because confirms the possibility of detecting the presence of NiO in spent FCC catalysts close the limits imposed by regulations (0.1 wt%). The same diffraction data were used to plot the calibration curve, useful for determining the content of bunsenite possibly present in the catalysts, according to the classical external standard method. To do this, the integrated intensity of the most intense reflection of bunsenite (200) located at ∼43.3° 2θ (Fig. 3) was used. As can be seen in Fig. 4 , the intensity of this reflection increases linearly with increasing content of Ni, according to the following equation: (1) I NiO = 0.1555 [ NiO ] r 2 = 0.9983 where I NiO is the integrated intensity of the reflection (200) of bunsenite and [NiO] is the content of the same phase in ppmw. 4.2.2 Samples Ni2+/Al2O3 Due to the presence of alumina in the FCC catalyst formulation, some studies have been performed on reference Ni2+/Al2O3 system. XRD studies show that the deposition of 4.7 wt% Ni on alumina followed by calcination (sample AL-1) does not result in the detection of bunsenite (Fig. 5 ), whereas NiO is observed on the catalyst containing at least 13.3 wt% Ni (AL-2). At the same time a careful investigation of the XRD patterns recorded from AL-X samples reveals a slight modification in the alumina support evidenced by a shift towards lower angular values of the peak at ∼67° 2θ. This peak is due to the (440) reflection of γ-Al2O3 and is the marker of a progressive increasing in the unit cell of the support as the Ni content increases. The change in the peak position is clearly detectable comparing the pure alumina sample with AL-1 and AL-2, whereas no further shift of the peak is observed for higher Ni loading, when instead the NiO content increases. The progressive enlargement of the unit cell of the support is reasonable due to a strong interaction of Ni with γ-Al2O3. It is in fact well known that γ-Al2O3 has a defective spinel type structure [16] strictly correlated to that of NiAl2O4 (nickel aluminate, an inverse spinel). It is also known that solid solutions with stoichiometries Ni x Al2O3+x can form [17], retaining the common spinel-type structure. The formation of Ni x Al2O3+x phase is therefore strongly supported in AL-X samples, with a degree of Ni substitution depending on its loading if segregation of NiO cannot be detected. Thus, the segregation of NiO starts above a critical Ni loading. In fact, considering the area of the support, the surface density of Ni atoms which has been deposed on the alumina surface in AL-1 may be considered to be well lower than that needed to cover the surface with a theoretical monolayer. Whereas, the surface density of Ni calculated for AL-2, nearly 10Å2 per Ni atom, is likely similar to that needed to completely cover the surface, and for Al-3 the virtual value of 3Å2 per Ni atom indicates that the theoretical monolayer coverage is exceeded. Thus, XRD-detectable NiO (bunsenite) is observed from the loading corresponding to the theoretical monolayer coverage and above. The Ni content in the AL-1 sample, where NiO is still not detected, corresponds to a virtual bulk composition Ni0.085Al2O3.085, while for the AL-2 sample (where NiO is starting to be observed) the corresponding virtual bulk formula is Ni0.27Al2O3.27. The difference between silica and alumina as supports for NiO is actually remarkable. As shown above on Ni2+/silica the NiO phase is observed by XRD already at 900ppmw Ni loading, while on Ni2+/Al2O3 bunsenite is still not detected at 4.7 wt% level, i.e. 47,000ppmw Ni loading. To collect further information on the role of alumina in the interaction with Ni, we performed UV–vis and TPR studies on AL-X samples. In Fig. 6 the UV–vis spectra of these samples are compared with that of pure NiO. The light green-blue color of the samples and the features of the visible spectra clearly indicate that Ni is in the form of Ni2+. The pure support alumina only shows an extremely weak absorption in the UV region likely associated to impurity charge transfer transition, not evident at the scale reported in the figure. The sample AL-1 shows a weak continuous rise of absorption in the UV region, without any maximum, and weak absorptions centered at 595, 625nm (sharp doublet) and at 1069nm (broad). This spectrum looks similar to that of the spinel NiAl2O4, that has been interpreted on the basis of d→d transitions of Ni2+ [18] as well as of other Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with a similar Ni content [19], discussed previously. The spectrum of AL-1 strongly differs from that of NiO that shows in the UV region something similar to an absorption plateau with two predominant components at 240 and 330nm, and, at lower energies, several components at 379, 418, 648, 719 and 1134nm (Fig. 6). The spectra of AL-2 and AL-3 show, in the UV region, much stronger absorption with two maxima at 255 and near 280nm while, above 350nm, are nearly the sum of those of NiO and of AL-1. Indeed in the spectrum of AL-3 the shoulder at 333nm, well evident in the subtraction spectrum (AL-3–AL-2) reported in the insert, and also in the visible region clearly show the presence of the features of bulk NiO, which are present, very weak, also in that of AL-2. In agreement with the conclusions obtained in a previous paper (where similar Ni2+/Al2O3 samples also containing silica as a stabilizing component have been investigated [19]), UV–vis spectra of AL-1 is due to highly dispersed Ni2+, strongly interacting with alumina. Additional information was derived from the Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) experiments performed on Al-1 sample and on pure NiO (Fig. 7 ). The TPR profile of NiO shows a peak at about 320°C, indicating that this phase is more easily reducible than the NiO/Al2O3 solid solution. In fact, the TPR curve of AL-1 sample shows a peak at much higher temperature (ca. 800°C, Fig. 7), while the lack of any reduction peak around 320°C indicates also that all Ni2+ is incorporated into the spinel-like phase and that NiO is not present even in trace amounts, in agreement with the XRD analysis (Fig. 5). The hydrogen consumption data indicate that the main reduction step occurred with total reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0. These results strongly support the conclusion that all Ni2+ is dispersed on the surface or in the subsurface of alumina forming a solid solution which strongly stabilizes the metal in its bivalent state. Moreover, the formation of the solid solution is quantitative at moderate Ni2+ loadings (4.7 wt%) as demonstrated by the fact that none of the characterization techniques employed (XRD analysis, UV–vis and TPR) evidenced the presence of even trace amounts of bunsenite (NiO). 4.2.3 CTZ samples The XRD patterns of the samples CTZ-1–CTZ-4, impregnated with increasing amounts of Ni, are shown in Fig. 8 . These patterns are dominated by the presence of sharp reflections associated with the Y zeolite (constituting 35–40 wt% of the catalyst) and broad and weaker reflections located at 45.6 and 67.1° 2θ, associated with the γ-Al2O3 matrix. Furthermore, the very weak reflections present in the 7–9° 2θ angular region are associated with small amounts of a second zeolite phase (ZSM-5) added to improve the octane number of the products in the gasoline range. Finally, a weak and broad incoherent scattering in the 15–35° 2θ angular region indicates the presence of an amorphous phase. To verify the effects associated with the treatment of the samples with increasing amounts of Ni, it is useful to consider first the regions where the (200) and (220) reflections of bunsenite are located. By examining in detail these spectral regions is evident how the patterns of the samples CTZ-1, CTZ-2 and CTZ-3 are very similar being present, in all cases, only a weak reflection whose intensity does not depend on the content of Ni (Fig. 9 ). For these samples, therefore, it is reasonable to exclude the presence of bunsenite. The same is not true in the case of the sample CTZ-4 since the reflections (200) and (220) of NiO are clearly visible in the XRD pattern reported in Figs. 8 and 9. Taking advantage of the calibration curve reported in Fig. 4, the concentration of bunsenite was estimated. Starting from the integrated intensity of the (200) reflection and applying equation (1) a concentration of NiO of ∼9000ppmw (∼0.9 wt%) was calculated. It corresponds to ∼7070ppmw of Ni, i.e. ∼10% of the total amount of Ni loaded in the sample (73,655ppmw, Table 1). This means that in the highly loaded CTZ-4 sample, 90% of Ni is still not in NiO form, only 10% producing NiO. The progressive shift towards lower angular values of the (440) reflection of γ-Al2O3 as the Ni content increases, already detected in AL-X samples, occurs also in CTZ samples. The accurate determination of position of the (440) reflection, performed by profile fitting, allowed to calculate the lattice parameter a of the cubic phase, which is plotted vs. the Ni content in Fig. 10 , together with the value reported in the literature for the stoichiometric spinel-type NiAl2O4 phase (a =8.052Å, file ICDD PDF-01-081-0718). It is evident that, within the experimental limits related to the complexity of the FCC catalyst and more important to the approximation used for evaluating the amount of Ni that has reacted with γ-Al2O3 in sample CTZ-4 (in which part of the metal segregates in form of NiO, Fig. 8), there is an expansion of the unit cell parameter of the spinel-like phase upon increasing the Ni content (Fig. 10). The linearity of this expansion indicates that the system follows a Vegard's type law typical of the solid solutions [20] and this finding strongly supports the preferential interaction of Ni2+ with γ-Al2O3. In several cases, an equation describing the expansion of the unit cell parameter (or volume in the case of non-isometric crystal systems) can be derived from the data collected on standard samples with known composition and this equation can be used for determining the composition of samples without the need to apply long and expensive elemental analysis methods. This is not case, however, for the CTZ samples since only the overall Ni content is known, while the exact amount of γ-Al2O3 is not provided by the catalyst's producer and it cannot be determined experimentally because of the presence of other Al-containing phases (USY zeolite and clay). Nevertheless, the linear variation of the unit cell parameter of the spinel-like phase coupled with the evidence provided by the XRD analysis regarding the absence of NiO in the CTZ samples up to 14,700ppmw Ni (i.e. much higher than those normally found in ECAT's (up to 5200ppmw, Table 1)), strongly supports the conclusion that Ni2+ quantitatively interacts with the γ-Al2O3 forming solid solutions of formula Ni x Al2O3+x . Indeed, a rough estimation of the composition of the spinel-like phase can be made by assuming that the a parameter of the cubic unit cell of the spinel-like phase linearly increases over the whole range of composition, i.e. from pure γ-Al2O3 to stoichiometric NiAl2O4. Within this approximation [21], we need to know the unit cell dimensions of these phases and apply the following equation: (2) a x = α γ - Al 2 O 3 0 ( 1 − X ) + α NiAl 2 O 4 0 ( X ) where a x is the unit cell parameter of sample containing a molar fraction X of NiAl2O4 (corresponding to x in Ni x Al2O3+x ), a γ − Al 2 O 3 0 and a NiAl 2 O 4 0 are the unit cell parameters of γ-Al2O3 and NiAl2O4, respectively. The value of a γ − Al 2 O 3 0 was set 7.892Å, corresponding to the intercept at [Ni]=0ppmw (pure γ-Al2O3) of the linear regression curve computed on the a values for samples CTZ-1–CTZ-3 (CTZ-4 was not considered due to the uncertainty related to the estimation of the NiO content, see above), while for a NiAl 2 O 4 0 a value of a =8.052Å was taken from the file ICDD PDF-01-081-0718. Starting from the experimental data reported in Fig. 10 for the CTZ samples, from Eq. (2) the rough composition of the spinel-like phase was computed giving the following results: Ni0.01Al2O3.01 for CTZ-1, Ni0.05Al2O3.05 for CTZ-2, Ni0.15Al2O3.15 for CTZ-3 and Ni0.52Al2O3.52 for CTZ-4. These data confirm that γ-Al2O3 reacts with Ni2+ and is able to trap significant amounts of metal, particularly when considering that, in the preparation of the CTZ samples, Ni was loaded in a single step, while in the real situation the catalyst is subjected to several reaction-regeneration cycles coming in contact with a feed containing a few tens of ppmw of Ni; this limits therefore the segregation phenomena of the metal, hence the formation of NiO particles, during the regeneration step. 4.2.4 ECAT samples After having verified the behavior of the model systems, we have examined a number of ECAT samples from some Italian refineries, characterized by different contents of Ni and other metals, such as V and Fe (Table 1). The XRD patterns of the ECAT samples investigated (ECAT-1–ECAT-10) are reported in Fig. 11 . A general inspection of the XRD patterns indicates that the main features of the ECAT samples are similar to those already discussed for the Ni-containing CTZ samples prepared in laboratory. The patterns are still dominated by the reflections of the Y zeolite, although the prolonged use of the catalysts in the FCC process has resulted in a broadening of the reflections themselves and in an overall loss of crystallinity with the consequent increase of the amorphous component. The reflections associated with the second zeolite component (ZSM-5) are stronger than in the case of the CTZ samples (Fig. 8) and this can be the result of the combination of the decrease in the crystallinity of the main phase (Y zeolite) and the different amount of additive (octane improver) added to the catalyst for operational reasons. A careful inspection of the same XRD patterns excludes the presence of reflections associated to NiO bunsenite. As in the case of the CTZ samples, the situation encountered in the XRD spectra of ECAT samples is very favorable to detect the presence of NiO even in trace amounts since the region of the spectrum close to the angular value where the most intense reflection of NiO is located ((200) at 43.3° 2θ) is essentially free of interferences. This is clearly demonstrated by the detailed inspection of the 42–45° 2θ region of the XRD patterns of the ECAT samples, where no scattering phenomena associated to NiO are detected (Fig. 12 ). On the other hand, in ECAT samples it is not possible to consider the shift of the (440) reflection as a proof of the formation of the Ni x Al2O3+x phase, since all the samples contain significant amounts of Fe (0.41–0.73 wt%, Table 1), which also forms solid solutions with alumina. 4.3 SEM–EDS studies of ECAT catalysts To verify the hypothesis of a strong interaction of Ni with γ-Al2O3 in ECAT samples, SEM–EDS mapping was performed. In Fig. 13 the spatial distributions of Al, Si and Ni in an ECAT-7 catalyst particle, chosen among the others for being that with the highest Ni loading, are reported. The maps show that aluminum is mainly surrounding the silicon-rich phases in agreement with the well-known role of γ-Al2O3 as binder in the FCC catalyst. Comparing the Ni-map with the Al and Si-maps, it can be observed a preferred location of Ni in Al rather than in Si-rich areas (corresponding to the USY zeolite crystals and clay particles). Furthermore, local EDS analyses were performed on a number of 50 different points in ECAT-8–10 catalysts. The SEM image of a portion of ECAT-8 catalyst is reported, as an example, in Fig. 14 and an average of the resulting EDS analyses are listed in Table 2 . The composition measured in point A is reasonably corresponding to that of REY zeolite while that of point D is due to an alumina-rich particle. Ni was found contaminating alumina not zeolite. The results obtained show that the zeolite-rich (points A, Si>Al, La present), the clay-rich (points B, Si≈Al, no La) and the silica-rich (points C, Si>85 wt% among elements different from oxygen, according to the EDS analysis) parts of the catalytic material are usually without Ni, while the alumina rich particles (points D, Al>80 wt% among elements different from oxygen) systematically contain Ni. On the other hand, points with Ni content higher than 4 wt% among elements different from oxygen, according to the EDS analysis, have never been revealed. Even though the element analysis by EDS is affected by significant error, and the analysis of fifty points may be not fully statistically significant, these analyses suggest that even in real ECAT samples, Ni is deposed essentially in the alumina-rich particles. 5 Discussion The data reported above indicate that nickel in spent FCC catalysts is not present as NiO (bunsenite). As demonstrated above, carefully performed XRD measurements allow detection of NiO already at 900ppmw of Ni loading (0.114 wt% of NiO) on SiO2 supports. In contrast, in CTZ samples, i.e. fresh FCC catalysts samples artificially loaded with Ni, NiO is not observed by XRD even in samples containing 14,700ppmw of metal. The same occurs on real ECAT catalysts (i.e. equilibrated catalysts downloaded from the regeneration unit of the FCC plant), in which NiO is not observed even on samples containing up to 5200ppmw of Ni (0.662 wt% of NiO). The absence of the NiO in both CTZ-1–3 and ECAT's is due to the presence of γ-Al2O3 in the catalyst formulation, which has the dual function to bind the other components of the catalysts itself (zeolite USY and clay particles), providing the necessary mechanical strength to the particles, and to act as a trap for the Ni2+ ions present in the feed in form of porphyrin-like complexes [5]. The latter, too hindered for entering the USY zeolite pores, decompose on the surface of alumina present in the catalyst. The high temperatures at which the catalyst is subjected in the different stages of the FCC process (even 700+°C in the regenerator, Fig. 1) promote the reaction of Ni2+ with the alumina binder, leading to the formation of the solid solution Ni x Al2O3+x . This is clearly demonstrated by the detection of a small but significant shift of the (440) reflection of the spinel-type γ-Al2O3 phase in the AL-X samples and, more precisely, by the accurate measurement of the parameter a of the cubic unit cell of γ-Al2O3 in CTZ sample, which linearly increases with the Ni2+ loading following a Vegard's type law that strongly indicates the formation of the Ni x Al2O3+x solid solutions (Fig. 10). In the spent FCC catalysts (ECAT's), the absence of NiO was confirmed by carefully examining the regions of the XRD pattern where the strongest reflections of this phase are expected. Due to the presence of significant amounts of Fe3+, deriving from the feedstock, it was not possible to check the shift of the (440) reflection of γ-Al2O3 for supporting the formation of the solid solution with Ni2+. In any case, the experimentation made on model systems as well as the SEM-EDS analysis performed on the spent catalysts unambiguously demonstrated that Ni2+ interacts with the alumina binder and does not segregate in form of NiO even for Ni loadings exceeding in large amounts those typical of the spent FCC catalyst. The data concerning Ni2+/Al2O3 samples show indeed that alumina allows spreading of large amounts of Ni as Ni2+ (from UV–vis spectra) and stabilizes them against reduction (TPR curves). Taking into account the high surface area of γ-Al2O3 (200–400m2/g) and its significant amount in the FCC catalyst, it is easy to calculate that the amount of Ni (up to ∼5200ppmw in our ECAT's) is such that a highly diluted Ni x Al2O3+x phase is formed, more than NiAl2O4. Thus alumina present in the catalyst makes Ni2+ ions essentially non-reducible in the conditions of FCC, or, at least, avoids the formation of extended Ni metal particles in the raiser reactor, where conditions are reducing. This avoids the occurrence of dehydrogenation reactions catalyzed by extended Ni metal particles, thus improving the catalyst activity for cracking reactions. Our data confirm those reported in the literature showing that alumina plays the role of “Ni-traps” [22], passivating nickel, as reported also in some patents [23–26]. As a secondary effect, the presence of such alumina-based Ni traps also avoids the formation of bulk NiO particles in the regenerator. As a result of this, spent FCC catalysts, which are extracted from the regenerator side in the oxidized state, do not really contain Ni as NiO but as highly diluted Ni x Al2O3+x phase, at least until Ni content is of the order of 5000–10,000ppmw. According to these data, spent FCC catalysts containing the usual content of Ni can be classified as non-hazardous wastes 6 Conclusions The extensive physico-chemical characterization of the spent FCC catalysts as well as of the model systems specially prepared for solving the debated question about the speciation of Ni led to the following conclusions: XRD technique allows to determine the presence of NiO at the level of 0.1 wt% and even less, corresponding to the limit imposed by the law to classify these materials as hazardous. The condition to achieve these levels of sensitivity is to collect diffraction data in a very accurate way, with long counting statistics and good quality of the data; in this way, it is possible to detect even very weak scattering phenomena in the regions where the reflections of the phase of interest (in this case, NiO) are expected. The absence of NiO in model systems for relatively low Ni2+ loadings but, in any case, much higher than those characteristic of spent FCC catalysts, has been confirmed also by other techniques including SEM–EDS, UV–vis and TPR. The experimental evidence confirm that γ-Al2O3 has the dual role of binder and of nickel trap, able to interact with the metal forming non-stoichiometric spinel-like phases with general formula Ni x Al2O3+x . The characterization performed on spent FCC catalysts employed in plants operating in some Italian refineries and containing up to 5200ppmw of Ni (virtually corresponding to 0.662 wt% NiO) excluded the presence of NiO. Based on these results, it can be concluded that the spent FCC catalysts do not contain NiO above the 0.1 wt% limit imposed by the law and that allows to classify them as “non-dangerous” waste. coredata.dc:description: The speciation of Ni in spent Fluid Catalytic Cracking catalysts is studied. Carefully performed XRD analyses with NiO/SiO2 samples used as calibration standards, demonstrate that the presence of NiO as a separate phase is reliably detected also for NiO concentration close to 0.1 wt% (1000ppmw). Actually, both on real spent FCC catalysts (ECAT's) and on artificially contaminated industrial FCC catalysts, NiO is not detectable as a separate phase, even after contamination of the order of 15,000ppmw of Ni. SEM–EDS experiments provide evidence of a largely preferential location of Ni on alumina particles present in the FCC catalyst mixture, thus acting as “nickel traps”. XRD, UV–vis and TPR data confirm that Ni deposits on alumina particles forming a hardly reducible surface and subsurface layer, giving rise to a solid whose composition is Ni x Al2O3+x with x <<0.25. As a result of this, the formation of extended Ni metal particles in the raiser reactor is avoided, being their unwanted dehydrogenation activity essentially eliminated. The absence of bulk NiO in the spent FCC catalysts (at least when Ni content is in the range 2000–10,000ppmw) allows the classification of this material as a non-hazardous waste.
coredata.dc:title: The state of nickel in spent Fluid Catalytic Cracking catalysts
